title: James Hoffmann's Ultimate AeroPress
preparation_steps: Place a paper filter into the AeroPress cap (do NOT rinse) and twist it onto the main chamber.
Place the AeroPress upright directly onto your cup or server.
Weigh out 11 g of coffee and grind to the finer end of medium.
Bring 200 g of water to a boil and let it rest ~15–30 s (or use 95 °C).
Add the ground coffee to the AeroPress chamber; make sure the bed is level.

brewing_steps.instruction: Place setup on scale, tare to zero. Start timer and pour 200 g hot water over coffee evenly (aim to wet all grounds).
brewing_steps.audio_script: Alright, now we're ready to start brewing. Place your AeroPress setup on the scale and tare it to zero. Start your timer and begin pouring 200 grams of hot water over the coffee grounds. Pour evenly in a circular motion, starting from the center and working your way outward. Make sure to wet all the grounds - you want complete saturation. This should take about 10 seconds. The coffee will start to bloom and release its gases, which is exactly what we want.

brewing_steps.instruction: Immediately insert plunger about 1 cm to create a partial vacuum seal (do not press).
brewing_steps.audio_script: Now, immediately after pouring, take the plunger and insert it about 1 centimeter into the AeroPress chamber. This is crucial - you want to create a partial vacuum seal that will prevent the coffee from dripping through too quickly. Don't press down, just insert it enough to create that seal. This technique is what makes James Hoffmann's method special - it controls the extraction time perfectly.

brewing_steps.instruction: Let coffee steep (first phase) — wait until ~2:00 on the timer.
brewing_steps.audio_script: Perfect! Now we wait for the first steeping phase. The coffee needs to extract for about 2 minutes - that's until the timer reaches 2:00. During this time, the hot water is extracting all the wonderful flavors, oils, and compounds from the coffee grounds. You'll notice the coffee bed has settled and the extraction is happening slowly and evenly thanks to that vacuum seal we created. This is where patience pays off - don't rush this step.

brewing_steps.instruction: Gently swirl the AeroPress (hold brewer + cup together) for ~5–10 s to agitate the slurry.
brewing_steps.audio_script: Now it's time for a gentle swirl. Hold both the AeroPress and your cup together firmly - you don't want them to separate during this step. Give the whole setup a gentle swirl for about 5 to 10 seconds. This agitates the coffee slurry and ensures even extraction by redistributing the grounds. You'll see the coffee swirling around - this helps break up any channels that might have formed and ensures all the coffee grounds are participating in the extraction.

brewing_steps.instruction: Let rest ~30 s (until ~2:30).
brewing_steps.audio_script: After that swirl, we let the coffee rest for another 30 seconds - until the timer reaches 2:30. This brief rest period allows the agitated grounds to settle again and gives the extraction just a little more time to work its magic. You'll notice the coffee has a nice, even color now, and the aroma should be fantastic. We're almost ready for the final step - the press.

brewing_steps.instruction: Slow, steady press the plunger down — aim for ~20–30 s press time — stop when you hear a soft hiss or when fully depressed.
brewing_steps.audio_script: Now for the final step - the press. Apply slow, steady pressure to the plunger and press it down gradually. This should take about 20 to 30 seconds - don't rush it. You want consistent, even pressure throughout the press. Listen carefully - when you hear a soft hiss, that means you've reached the end and should stop pressing. That hiss indicates that most of the liquid has been extracted and you're starting to compress the coffee bed. And there you have it - James Hoffmann's ultimate AeroPress coffee!

notes: James Hoffmann's Ultimate AeroPress Technique — 11g coffee, 200g water, no filter rinse, finer end of medium grind, immediate plunger insertion, 2 min steep + 30s rest before pressing. Adjust temperature between 95–100 °C based on roast level.

title: Tim Wendelboe Classic AeroPress
preparation_steps: Rinse a paper filter under hot water for a few seconds and place it in the AeroPress cap (this removes papery taste and warms the cap).
Assemble the AeroPress in standard position placed on your cup or server.
Weigh 14 g of coffee and grind to a fine 'filter' consistency (finer than medium-fine).
Bring water to a boil and let rest ~5–10 s (or use ~96 °C). Prepare your scale and timer.

brewing_steps.instruction: Place AeroPress on scale, tare. Start timer and quickly pour 200 g hot water evenly over the grounds.
Stir the slurry 3 times (back-to-front is common in the café method).
Insert the plunger about 1 cm to create a seal and prevent drainage. Let steep for 30 seconds.
After 30 s, remove plunger and stir gently 3 times back-to-front (this re-mixes the bed).
Re-insert plunger and press steadily; aim for ~15–25 s press time and stop when you hear the soft hiss (do not over-press).

notes:
Based on the classic recipe used at Tim Wendelboe's café: 14g/200g, near-boiling water, rinsed filter, 60s infusion, stirring and pressing. Adjust the dose if you want more/less intensity (see variants).

What to expect:

A clean, sweet, and vibrant cup highlighting the coffee's acidity and clarity.

Light, bright flavor with pronounced fruity and floral notes (especially if using specialty light roasts).

Balanced and nuanced with minimal bitterness and little astringency when brewed with precision.

This method brings out the best in high-quality beans, letting their origin character shine through. It's ideal for single-origin light to medium roasted coffees.

title: Championship Concentrate AeroPress
preparation_steps: Rinse a paper filter under hot water and fit it into the AeroPress cap (this removes papery taste and pre-warms the cap).
Assemble the AeroPress in inverted position (plunger at the bottom, chamber open on top) and place on the scale.
Weigh 20 g of coffee and grind to a fine, filter-leaning consistency (slightly finer than typical filter).
Bring water to boil and let rest ~5–10 s (use ~94 °C). Have scale and timer ready.

brewing_steps.instruction: Start timer, tare scale and pour 100 g hot water evenly over the grounds.
Stir vigorously for ~10 seconds to ensure full saturation and uniform extraction.
Quickly wipe any drips, screw on the rinsed filter cap and wait (keep inverted).
brewing_steps.short_instruction: Wipe drips • Screw on filter cap

brewing_steps.instruction: Let steep until ~1:20 on the timer (total steep ≈ 60–70 s after stirring).
Carefully flip the AeroPress onto your cup/server and press steadily; aim for a 20–30 s press until fully depressed.

notes: High-concentration competition method: 20g/100g, 94°C, fine grind, controlled agitation (~10s), ~60-70s steep before flipping and 20-30s press. Dilute to taste or use as base for milk drinks.

title: 2024 World AeroPress Champion - George Stanica (Romania) - Inverted
preparation_steps: Rinse one Aesir paper filter with hot water and fit it in the cap (removes papery taste).
Assemble the AeroPress in inverted position and align it approx. to the 4th mark.
Weigh 18 g of coffee and grind to medium-coarse (Comandante C40 Mk4, ~58 clicks / ~870 µm).
Add the 18 g ground coffee to the inverted AeroPress and give a gentle shake to level the bed.
Prepare extraction water (96 °C) and a Melodrip (or similar) for controlled pours. Have scale and timer ready.

brewing_steps.instruction: Start timer and pour 50 g of 96 °C water using the Melodrip (aim 5–6 s for the pour). Allow the coffee to bloom: wait ~30 s (bloom period ends ~00:35).
Pour the second 50 g of 96 °C water (again ~5–6 s pour).
Stir gently in a North–South–East–West (NSEW) pattern for ~10 s to homogenize.
At 1:05 (≈65 s) screw on the rinsed cap and gently press to remove excess air (~10 s).
brewing_steps.short_instruction: Screw on cap • Press out air

brewing_steps.instruction: Give a gentle swirl to the AeroPress, place it onto your serving vessel, and begin the slow, controlled press. Aim to finish pressing within 30–40 s. Target yield: ~76–79 g of concentrate.
brewing_steps.short_instruction: Swirl gently • Place on vessel • Press 30-40s

brewing_steps.instruction: When press is complete, add warm water until total weight reaches 130–135 g (bypass step).
Add an additional 20–30 g of room-temperature 0 ppm water for balance (final total ≈150–165 g depending on target).

equipment: Comandante C40 Mk4 (or equivalent) for grind reference
notes: Recipe by George Stanica (World Champ 2024). Focus on precise water chemistry and two pours for controlled saturation. Bypass at two temperatures (hot water for strength and 0 ppm water at room temperature for balance and clarity). The medium-coarse grind and slow pressing seek clarity while avoiding over-extraction.

title: 2023 World AeroPress Champion - Tay Wipvasutt (Thailand) - Inverted
preparation_steps: Rinse and place a paper filter in the cap, if you prefer; assemble AeroPress inverted.
Weigh 18 g total: prepare 16 g to add initially and keep 2 g set aside for later addition.
Grind to the competition setting (1ZPresso ZP6, 65 clicks).
Heat Perfect Coffee Water to 89 °C. Prepare scale and timer.

brewing_steps.instruction: Place 16 g of grounds in the inverted AeroPress. Start timer and pour 100 g of 89 °C water over the grounds. Then stir for ~5 s to agitate and homogenize the slurry.
At 0:45, add the remaining 2 g of coffee (late addition).
At 0:55, stir again for ~5 s to incorporate the late addition.
Slightly press the plunger up to remove excess air, then securely close the cap.
Carefully flip the AeroPress and begin pressing at 1:40 (≈100 s). Press steadily for ~30 s. Target yield: ~75 g concentrate.
Bypass the concentrate with room-temperature water until total weight reaches 115 g (first bypass).
Then add hot water until total weight reaches 155 g (second bypass / final tempered).

notes: Technique by Tay Wipvasutt (World Champ 2023). Use of 'late addition' (2g added at 0:45) to introduce fresh aromatic compounds without over-extracting the main body. Bypass in two stages (room-temp and hot) to control strength and final temperature.

title: 2022 World AeroPress Champion - Jibbi Little (Australia) - Inverted

parameters.grind_size: Dual-grind then sifted (coarse via Timemore -> refined on Kinu #4); fines removed (100–200 µm)

preparation_steps: Prepare and sift grounds per method: coarse grind (Timemore) → refine on Kinu #4 → sift to remove fines (100–200 µm).
Rinse a paper filter and place in the cap; assemble AeroPress inverted.
Weigh 18.0 g of the prepared grounds and add them to the chamber.
Heat Perfect Coffee Water to 92 °C for extraction and prepare 90 °C water for bypass.

brewing_steps.instruction: Start timer and pour 94 ml of 92 °C water evenly over the grounds. Then stir gently 35 times (steady, gentle strokes) to ensure full saturation—this will take ~30–40 s depending on pace.
At 1:20 (≈80 s) screw on the rinsed filter cap and press out any remaining air from the chamber.
brewing_steps.short_instruction: Screw on cap • Press out air

brewing_steps.instruction: At 1:30 (≈90 s) flip the AeroPress carefully onto your server and begin pressing. Press steadily for ~30 s.
Complete the press (target window between 1:40 and 2:10; typical yield ≈58–64 g concentrate).
Bypass the concentrate with 90 °C water until total weight reaches 150 g.
Optional: add 4 chilled ice balls for smoother mouthfeel (ice-bypass technique) if serving cold or to rapidly lower temperature.

equipment: Jar for dilutions / ice if applicable
notes: Advanced technique by Jibbi Little (World Champ 2022). Use of dual grinder and sieving for extreme control of particle distribution; many gentle revolutions for saturation (35 stirs) and bypass at 90°C up to 150g to achieve desired texture and temperature. Ideal for competitions and demonstrations of clarity and texture.

title: 2021 World AeroPress Champion - Tuomas Merikanto (Finland) - Inverted
preparation_steps: Weigh 18.0 g of coffee and grind on Macap Labo 70D at setting 7.0.
Assemble the AeroPress in inverted position and place on the scale.
Prepare Third Wave Water Formula 2 and heat to 80 °C.
Have pitcher and target server ready for the 'pour from altitude' stage.

brewing_steps.instruction: Add 18.0 g of grounds to the inverted AeroPress. Start timer and add 50 g of 80 °C water between 0:00–0:10 (gentle pour).
From 0:10–0:15, stir very gently 3 times back and forth.
From 0:15–0:30 continue pouring water gradually until total poured reaches 200 g (slow, controlled pour).
At 0:50, stir very gently 3 more times to re-homogenize the bed.
At 1:00 (≈60 s), push out any excess air from the chamber and attach the filter cap; allow brewing until ~1:40 (≈100 s).
brewing_steps.short_instruction: Press out air • Attach filter cap

brewing_steps.instruction: At ~1:35 place your pitcher on top of the AeroPress; at 1:40 (≈100 s) flip the brewer carefully.
Immediately begin pressing from 1:40–2:00 (≈20 s press).
From 2:00–2:30 (≈120–150 s) swirl the brewed coffee and perform a 'pour from altitude' into another pitcher to aerate and cool.

equipment: Third Wave Water Formula 2 (or prepared mineral profile)
notes: Recipe by Tuomas Merikanto (World Champ 2021). Focus on water chemistry (TWW Formula 2), two pouring stages with a low extraction point (80°C) and manipulation techniques (very gentle stirs, quick flip and press) followed by 'pour from altitude' for aeration and cooling.
